seriesstmt.p: Portions of this collection are part of New England's Hidden Histories. Digital historical representations of these portions of the collection can be viewed online.

maintenanceevent.eventdescription: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday June 1, 2022 at 19:29

did.abstract: The land encompassing today's Newton was first settled by English colonizers in 1630 as part of "the newe towne." In 1681, Cambridge Village was incorporated as a separate town from Cambridge and in 1691 the town was renamed Newtown. The town name was changed yet again in 1766 to Newton. The first meeting house was built in 1660. John Elliot Jr. was installed as the first pastor. The second meeting house was constructed in 1698. In 1720, and again in 1770, the homes of John Cotton and later Jonas Meriam were destroyed by fire and with them the earliest records of the church. The third meeting house was built in 1721 with subsequent meeting houses constructed in 1805, 1847, and 1904. In 1764, a group of parishioners in the western part of Newton built their own meeting house to hold Sunday services, and in 1781 they formally gathered the West Parish Church. In 1972 the First Church in Newton dissolved after more than three hundred years of service to the Newton community. This collection contains the administrative records of the First Church in Newton, Massachusetts, as well as the records of the members and ministers of the church.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted and open to the public.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Items in this collection are subject to U.S. Copyright Law. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine the copyright status of collection items and to secure any permissions necessary for their reproduction and publication. Requests for permission to publish material must be discussed with the archivist or librarian.

Digital Reproductions are protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use the Digital Reproductions in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. In addition, no permission is required from the Congregational Library & Archives for educational uses. For other uses, you need to obtain permission from the Congregational Library & Archives. For additional information regarding copyright, please consult the Congregational Library & Archives' Digital Collections Copyright & Use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], in the Newton, Mass. First Church records, 1664-1974, RG0132. The Congregational Library & Archives, Boston, MA.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Initial collection was donated to the Congregational Library & Archives by the First Congregational Church in Newton, Massachusetts, in 1972 following the dissolution of the church; no accession number.
An additional accession of a photograph album was added to the collection in 2013; no accession number.
A folder of papers from Samuel Back were transferred to this collection from the The Congregational Christian Church and the Evangelical and Reformed Church Merger Collection (RG5387); 2019-18.
A Cookbook from the Women's Benevolent Society was donated to the Congregational Library & Archives by Myra Dodick in July 2019; 2019-21.

altformavail.head: Digital Copies
altformavail.p: Records within this collection were digitized as part of the New England's Hidden Histories project. Digital reproductions may be accessed online through our digital archive.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional accruals are expected for this collection in the form of full-text transcription. There is no anticipated date for this accrual.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Originally process by Sandra Sudak in 1990. Additional processing by Albertina M. Rua in 2003. Re-processed by Zachary Bodnar, May 2022, using DACS Second Edition.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The land encompassing today's Newton was first settled by English colonizers in 1630 as part of "the newe towne," though the lands of this new town were within the traditional tribal lands of the Massachusett peoples. The "newe towne" was renamed to Cambridge in 1638. In 1646 the missionary John Eliot and a small band of Native Americans lead by Waban settled the village of Nonantum, from the Algonquian term for rejoicing, in an area of Cambridge that would be today's Newton. Nonantum became the first of John Eliot's "praying Indian villages." However, five years later, Eliot and Waban were forced to relocate the village and its people to present day Natick due to the insatiable land hunger of the colonists in nearby Cambridge and Boston. In 1681, Cambridge Village was incorporated as a separate town from Cambridge and in 1691 the town was renamed Newtown. The town name was changed yet again in 1766 to Newton.

The first meeting house, built on the site of today's Old Burying Ground, in Newton was built in 1660 by parishioners who had tired of making the trip to Cambridge proper for Sunday worship. In 1664 the Massachusetts General Court granted the parishioners of this area leave to form their own church, the First Congregational Church. That same year John Elliot Jr. was installed as the first pastor of the newly gathered church. The second meeting house was constructed in 1698 across the street from the first meeting house. In 1720, and again in 1770, the homes of John Cotton and later Jonas Meriam were destroyed by fire and with them the earliest records of the church.

In 1721, the church was ordered by the General Court to move their building; that same year saw the construction of the third meeting house and all subsequent meeting houses would be built on the same land. In 1764, a group of parishioners in the western part of Newton built their own meeting house to hold Sunday services, and in 1781 they formally gathered the West Parish Church. The fourth meeting house was constructed in 1805. The Federal Street Church in Boston gifted First Church its first bell in 1810. The first Sunday school was established in 1816. The fifth meeting house was constructed in 1847.

In 1895, the church and parish organizations incorporated as a single organization. The sixth, and final, meeting house was constructed in 1904. During the 1940s the First Church contemplated the formation of a federated church with the First Baptist Church in Newton, but did not follow through. In 1972 the First Church in Newton dissolved after more than three hundred years of service to the Newton community.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the administrative records of the First Church in Newton, Massachusetts, as well as the records of the members and ministers of the church. The collection includes church meeting minutes, financial records for the church and building, papers and sermons from ministers, church bulletins and calendars, vital membership records, scrapbooks, diaries, programs, and photographic materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged into the six topical series listed below. Some of those series contain topical sub-series which are also listed below. Within each series materials are arranged in chronological order. When appropriate, closely related and/or continuous materials have been arranged together.
Sub-series 2: Admissions, dismissions, and membership records, 1869-1969
Sub-series 2: Women's Benevolent and Church Aid Society, 1861-1974
Sub-series 6: Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor, 1887-1916

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: To access digital materials on our digital archive, it is strongly recommended that you use the latest available version of Microsoft Edge, Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Safari (Apple).

persname.part: First Baptist Church in Newton (Newton Center, Newton, Mass.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to the administration of the church and includes meeting minutes, annual reports, clerk's records, church correspondence, photographs, and anniversary-related records.

did.unittitle: Confession of faith and covenant signers
Final service program and annotated photographic printouts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series, which contains three sub-series, contains records relating to the members of the First Church and includes vital records, such as baptismal and marriage records, records of admissions and dismissions, records relating to members, and member registers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains registers, lists of members, and membership indexes.

did.unittitle: Alphabetical index to chronological membership list

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains records of admissions and dismissions as well as records relating to the membership and makeup of the First Church and includes photograph albums, membership records, applications and transfer documents, and correspondence.

did.unittitle: War of 1812 and Spanish-American War veterans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains vital records for the members of the First Church and includes baptismal records, marriage records, and records of deaths.

did.unittitle: Deaths: memorandum of data for church records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series, which contains three sub-series, contains records relating to the finances of the First and includes records directly relating to finances and financial records, records relating to the maintenance of the church building, and records relating to pews and pew owners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains records relating the finances of the First Church and includes bills and receipts, cash books, ledgers and account books, fundraising records, and parish subscriber records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains records related to the upkeep of the physical church and includes deeds, building committee records, photographs of church building interiors and exteriors, and building assessments.

did.unittitle: 6th meeting house cornerstone and construction photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains records relating to pews and pew owners and includes pew ledgers, correspondence, pew bills of sales, and records related to the use and maintenance of the horse shed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains records from auxiliary groups and committees from the First Church in Newton. Included in this series are meeting minutes, scrapbooks, financial records, bulletins, annual reports, and a cook book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains records related to the operation of the Sunday school and includes superintendent's records and attendance records.

did.unittitle: Sunday school primary department attendance records
Sunday school junior department attendance records
Women's Benevolent and Church Aid Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records of the Women's Benevolent and Church Aid Society. The group was originally known as the Ladies Benevolent and Church Aid Society and in its later years was frequently simply called the Women's Benevolent Society. This sub-series includes meeting minutes, financial records, histories, a cook book, and constitutions.

did.unittitle: Ladies Benevolent Society Church Aid Department financial records
Ladies' Benevolent Society Home Missionary Department financial records
Ladies' Benevolent Society Local Charity General Expense Fund financial records
Women's Benevolent Society dues and pledges
Women's Benevolent Society dues and pledges
Choice Recipes from Members and Friends of the Women's Benevolent Society
Women's Benevolent Society officers and constitution
Women's Benevolent Society pamphlets and musical
Diposition of Women's Benevolent Society assets

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the financial records of the Benevolence Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains a single record book from the Little People's Mission group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records and correspondence of the Furber Society.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Materials in this folder were removed from the Furber Society records, 1903-1915.

did.unittitle: Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records and bulletins of the Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Materials in this folder were removed from Christian Endeavour Society records, 1902-1905

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records of the Ladies Foreign Missionary Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains a record book from the Ladies Furnishing Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records of the Kelsey Circle. Starting in 1962, some Kelsey Circle documents suggest that the group became a part of the Women's Benevolent Society, though it seems to have continued on as a largely independent group even after 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains records from the Men's Club and includes a scrapbook, correspondence, and annual reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the records of the Friendly Service Committee which was originally known as the Sewing Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains a volume of records from the Reading Committee.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains papers, photographs, sermons, correspondence, diaries, and scrapbooks from the various ministers of the First Church in Newton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains a sermon from Nathaniel Appleton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the papers, sermons, and spiritual diary of Jonathan Homer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the papers of Daniel L. Furber and includes collected sermons, correspondence, travel diaries, and photographs.

did.unittitle: James F. C. Hyde memorial address
Daniel L. Furber funeral service materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains sermons and a biographical sketch from Theodore J. Holmes.

did.unittitle: Theodore J. Holmes sermons and biographical sketch

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains sermons, papers, and correspondence from Edward M. Noyes. This sub-series also contains records about the Edward M. Noyes memorial window.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains sermons from Jay T. Stocking and also includes a memorial scrapbook for Jay T. Stocking.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the papers of Dwight J. Bradley.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: This sub-series contains the sermons and papers of Morrison Russell Boynton and also includes lectures and photographs.

did.unittitle: M. Russell Boynton beach quiet hour lectures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the papers of Nathanael M. Guptill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the papers of Frank M. Weiskel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains calendars, bulletins, and other serial publications produced by the First Church in Newton.
